Questions.QuestionString: How many modes do the aileron actuators operate in: (Level 1)
Answers: three modes: active, damping and centering

Questions.QuestionString: Elevators are controlled by: (Level 1)
The THS is controlled by: (Level 1)
Which surfaces are mechanically controlled in emergency operation: (Level 2)
Which Modes exist for an elevator servo control actuator: (Level 2)
The rudder travel limitation function is a function of: (Level 2)
If ELAC1 and ELAC2 have failed: (Level 1)
Answers: all aileron actuators revert to damping mode
all aileron actuator revert to active mode
01 aileron actuator on each side reverts to damping mode

Questions.QuestionString: Which surfaces are used for LAF(Load Alleviation Function) on A320 aircrafts: (Level 1)
What effect on the slat and flap system will the failure of 01 SFCC cause: (Level 1)
Answers: slat and flap systems are controlled by the other computer and the systems operate normally
slat and flap systems operate at half speed
slat and flap systems are locked

Questions.QuestionString: What is purpose of Alpha/speed lock function of the SFCCs: (Level 2)
Answers: inhibit slats retraction at high angle of attack
inhibit flaps retraction at low speeds
inhibit flaps retraction at high angle of attack and low speeds

Questions.QuestionString: Which normally controls the elevators and THS? (Level 2)
Which control the THS actuator? (Level 2)
Which normally controls the ailerons? (Level 3)
ALL aileron actuators revert to damping mode in case of(Level 3)
Answers: Green and Blue hydraulic low pressure

Questions.QuestionString: In manual flight, which command the yaw damping, turn coordination and rudder trim (Level 2)
Answers: The ELACs transmit the command to the FACs

Questions.QuestionString: The rudder is powered by (Level 3)
Answers: Three hydraulic actuators operating in parallel

Questions.QuestionString: If the AOA protection is activated with speed brakes extended (Level 3)
Answers: The speed brakes stay in the last position
The speed brakes are automatically retracted

Questions.QuestionString: Which command the control valve spool for retraction (RET) or extension (EXT) the S/F system(Level 3)
What happens when both SFCCS detect any flap disconnection(Level 3)
Answers: The system is stopped by the Pressure Off Brakes
The Wing Tip Brakes are applied

Questions.QuestionString: When the flaps reach the demanded position(Level 2)
Answers: The motor runs and the Pressure Off Brake (POB) is released
The motor stops and the Pressure Off Brake (POB) is released
All solenoid valves are de-energized and the POB is applied.

Questions.QuestionString: In case of SFCC no2 failure: (Level 3)
Answers: Slat system operates at half speed
Flap system operates at half speed
Slat and flap systems operate at half speed

Questions.QuestionString: EFCS (electrical flight control system) consists of: (Level 3)
If both FACâ€™s fail, is maximum rudder deflection available? (Level 3)
Is there any feedback in the rudder pedals from the yaw damping or turn coordination functions? (Level 3)
Answers: From yaw damping function: yes , from turn coordination function: NO

Questions.QuestionString: There is a mechanical back up on the: (Level 2)
All flight control surfaces are: (Level 2)
The pitch control is achieved by: (Level 2)
Answers: Two elevators and the two Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS).
Two elevators and the Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS).

Questions.QuestionString: The roll control is achieved by: (Level 3)
Answers: One aileron and spoilers number 2,3,4 and 5 on each wing.
One aileron and spoilers number 2,3,4 on each wing.
Two aileron and spoilers number 3,4,5 on wing.

Questions.QuestionString: If the active elevator actuator fails, what occurs? (Level 3)
Answers: Control is transferred the other actuator.
THS is used to achive the pitch control

Questions.QuestionString: The A321 is equipped with: (Level 3)
The ground spoiler function is activated(Level 3)
Answers: As soon as both MLG legs are compressed
As soon as one MLG leg is compressed
As soon as NLG leg is compressed

Questions.QuestionString: The ground spoiler function is activated to: (Level 3)
Answers: Destroy the lift at touch-down and roll-out phases.
Destroy the lift at touch-down and roll-out phases or aborted take-off.

Questions.QuestionString: The slat and flap indications are displayed on: (Level 3)
Under normal law, what does ELAC# 1 control? (Level 3)
Answers: Standby - Elevator / Stabilizer control (backs up ELAC 2)

Questions.QuestionString: Spoiler surface can be raised manually in (Level 2)
Which controls the pressure off brake (POB) in slat/flap system (Level 2)
If the active elevator servocontrol fails, what occurs? (Level 2)
Answers: Control is transferred the other actuator.
THS is used to achive the pitch control

Questions.QuestionString: If a spoiler has failed, how does the system compensate for undesirable yaw? (Level 2)
Answers: Inhibition of the symmetrical spoiler on the other wing.

Questions.QuestionString: What computer normally commands the operation of the elevators and horizontal stabilizer? (Level 2)
In Pitch Normal Law Flight Mode; pitch trim is: (Level 2)
Answers: Automatic as long as the autopilot is engaged.
Automatic with or without the autopilot engaged.

Questions.QuestionString: When asymmetry or runaway or overspeed is detected on slat/flap system(Level 2)
Answers: The Wing Tip Brakes (WTBs) stop and hold the transmission.
The Pressure Off Brakes are applied in order to stop the transmission
The slat/flap surfaces extend (retract) at half speed.

Questions.QuestionString: What computer normally controls the elevators and THS(Level 2)
Which following statement concerning aileron is true (Level 2)
Answers: Two aileron actuators for each aileron, The one actuates the surface is called active servo control
The second one which follows the surface deflection is in damping mode.

Questions.QuestionString: The ailerons are controlled from (Level 3)
Answers: The side stick controllers or automatically in autopilot function

Questions.QuestionString: The left or right elevator actuators are connected to(Level 2)
Answers: Two computers: one ELAC and one SEC
Two computers: one ELAC and one FAC
Two computers: one FAC and one SEC

Questions.QuestionString: In the event of the loss of control of the two servo-controls of the elevator (Level 3)
Answers: An overriding mechanism gives the priority to the mechanical control over the electrical control
The servocontrols are automatically switched to a centering mode and hold the surface in the neutral position
The damping mode becomes automatically engaged

Questions.QuestionString: The input shaft of the THS actuator is normally driven by(Level 3)
Answers: An electrical motor servocontrolled by the ELAC 2, two other motors controlled respectively by ELAC 1 or SEC 1 and SEC 2.
Two electrical motors servocontrolled by the ELAC 1 and ELAC2, the other motor controlled respectively by SEC 1 or SEC 2.
One electrical motor servocontrolled by the ELAC 1 and one electrical motor servo controlled by the ELAC 2 one electrical motor servo controlled by the SEC 1 or SEC 2

Questions.QuestionString: Yaw damper servo actuators are normally controlled by (Level 3)
Answers: Both Flight Augmentation Computer FAC1 and FAC2 simultaneously
Flight Augmentation Computer (FAC) 1, the FAC 2 being in standby.
Flight Augmentation Computer (FAC) 2 and the FAC 1 in turns

Questions.QuestionString: To arm the ground spoilers(Level 2)
Answers: The speed brake lever must be pulled up when in RETRACTED position
The speed brake lever must be pulled up when in EXTENDED position
The speed brake lever has to be pushed down and placed in the required position.

Questions.QuestionString: In case of failure of both servo controls of a same aileron (Level 2)
Answers: The other aileron reverts to damping mode.
The other aileron is still operated.
The other aileron operates at half speed.

Questions.QuestionString: When a flap attachment failure is detected. (Level 3)
Answers: The flap PCU is de-energized and the pressure-off brakes are applied in order to stop the transmission.
The wing tip brakes (WTBs) are applied and stop and hold the transmission
The opposite flap operation still activate.

Questions.QuestionString: If an aileron hydraulic actuator servo controlfailure occur (Level 3)
Answers: You can dispatch the aircraft with related aileron hydraulic actuator servo controldeactivate
You can dispatch the aircraft with related and opposite aileron hydraulic actuator servo controldeactivate and
No need to deactivate the aileron hydraulic actuator servos control to dispatch the aircraft because it goes to damping mode

Questions.QuestionString: To deactivation of the spoiler servo control for flight? (Level 3)
Answers: When you deactivate a spoiler servo control, it is necessary to deactivate the symmetrical spoiler on the other wing
When you deactivate a spoiler servo control, it is not necessary to deactivate the symmetrical spoiler on the other wing
Not necessary to deactivate the spoiler servo control for flight because spoiler is inhibited automatically by the SEC

Questions.QuestionString: The high lift function is achieved by: (Level 1)
Answers: The slats, the flaps and the ailerons.
The slats, the flaps and the spoiler number 5.

Questions.QuestionString: In case of failure of both ELACs, the SECs: (Level 2)
Answers: Directly receive signals from the side sticks.
Directly receive signals from the FAC.
Still receive control signals via ELAC.

Questions.QuestionString: All protections are lost in: (Level 1)
The trimmable horizontal stabilizer driven by two hydraulic motors which is: (Level 2)
Answers: Controlled by one of the three electric motors.

Questions.QuestionString: Which computer normally control the rudder function? (Level 2)
Answers: FAC 1 has priority, FAC 2 is in hot stand-by.
FAC 2 has priority, FAC 1 is hot stand-by.

Questions.QuestionString: Which signals cause rudder pedal movements: (Level 1)
The Slat Flap control computer inhibits slat retraction from position 1 to 0: (Level 3)
Answers: At low angle of attack or low speed: alpha-lock function
At low angle of attack or high speed
At high angle of attack or low speed: alpha-lock function

Questions.QuestionString: With one SFCC inoperative, both slat and flap systems operate: (Level 2)
Answers: Depending on the faulty channel of the SFCC

Questions.QuestionString: A Pressure Off Brake on each motor locks the transmission when: (Level 3)
Answers: No drive commands or in case of hydraulic power failure.

Questions.QuestionString: Once applied the WTB can be: (Level 2)
Answers: Reset on ground only via the Centralized Fault Display System.

Questions.QuestionString: Which order do not move the rudder pedals (no feedback)? (Level 1)
The signal used to control and monitor the Slats/Flaps system is provided by: (Level 2)
Answers: A Feedback Position Pick Off Units.
An Asymmetry Position Pick Off Units.
An Instrumentation Position Pick Off Units.

Questions.QuestionString: If both FAC fail, what is configuration of Rudder Travel Limitation? (Level 3)
Answers: It is frozen immediately at last position.
Emergency control brings back to low speed configuration.

Questions.QuestionString: The trim able horizontal stabilizer driven by two hydraulic motors which is: (Level 2)
Answers: Controlled by one of the three electric motors.

Questions.QuestionString: How does THS feedback to the cockpit? (Level 1)
All flight control surfaces are: (level 1)
The pitch control is achieved by: (level 1)
Answers: Two elevators and the two Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS).
Two elevators and the Trimmable Horizontal Stabilizer (THS).

Questions.QuestionString: The roll control is achieved by: (level 1)
Answers: One aileron and spoilers number 2,3,4 and 5 on each wing.
One aileron and spoilers number 2,3,4 on each wing.
Two aileron and spoilers number 3,4,5 on wing.

Questions.QuestionString: If the active elevator actuator fails, what occurs? (level 2)
Answers: Control is transferred the other actuator.
THS is used to achive the pitch control

Questions.QuestionString: The elevator aileron computers (elacs) and spoiler elevator computers (secs) are able to: (level 2)
Answers: Control the aircraft in the roll and pitch axes.
Control the aircraft in the roll, yaw and pitch axes.
Control the aircraft in the roll and pitch axes with FAC standby.

Questions.QuestionString: How many flight augmentation computers (facs) control the yaw axis? (level 1)
The ground spoiler function is activated to: (level 2)
Answers: Destroy the lift at touch-down and roll-out phases.
Destroy the lift at touch-down and roll-out phases or aborted take-off.

Questions.QuestionString: The slat and flap indications are displayed on: (level 2)
In case of sfcc no2 failure : (level 2)
Answers: Slat system operates at half speed
Flap system operates at half speed
Slat and flap systems operate at half speed

Questions.QuestionString: If both facâ€™s fail , is maximum rudder deflection available ? (Level 2)
Is there any feedback in the ruder pedals from the yaw damping or turn coordination functions ? (Level 1)
Answers: From yaw damping function : yes , from turn coordination function : no

Questions.QuestionString: The wing tip brakes are: (Level 1)
Answers: Operated electrically by a control lever on the pedestal
Controlled by The SFCC and operated hydraulically.

Questions.QuestionString: Which modes exist for an Aileron servo control actuator ? (Level 1)
If the WTB'S lock the flap or slat surfaces and prevent further movement, can the remaining surfaces be extended? (Level 3)
Answers: If the flap (slat) WTBs are on, the slats (flaps) can be still operated
If the any WTBs are on, all slats and flaps are locked.
Only the locked side can not be extended

Questions.QuestionString: Rudder driven by: (Level 1)
Answers: 03 (Green, Blue, Yellow) Actuators which operates in parallel.
One Actuator which is in active mode and two other are in damping mode.
03 (Green, Blue, Yellow) Actuators which operates independently depend on pilots.

Questions.QuestionString: Which mode is adopted by the elevator servo control when both solenoid valves are de-energized, no electrical command signal is provided and hydraulic pressure is available? (Level 1)
What the purpose of torquelimiters in slat/flap system? (Level 3)
Answers: Protect the wing structure and the actuators from a torque overload which could occur by a slat/flap mechanism failure
Protect the wing structure and the actuators from asymmetry of slat/flap system
Holds the output shaft of slat/flap system when the select position is reached

Questions.QuestionString: Which operating modes does each ELEV servo control has? (Level 1)
When EFCS (ELECTRIC FLIGHT CONTROL SYSTEM) completely failed, the controls of rudder and THS are: (Level 1)
In case of SFCC2 failed, How are Slat and and Flap systems affected? (Level 1)
Answers: Slat system operates at half speed
Slat and flap systems operate at half speed
Slat and flap systems are locked

Questions.QuestionString: How many servo control actuators power the rudder surface? (Level 1)
Which signal causes the rudder pedal movement? (Level 1)
What is the active protections in direct law (Level 1)
Where are the torque limiters located? (Level 1)
The rudder travel limitation value is frozen immediately (Level 2)
Answers: And the rudder traveling is limited to lowspeed configuration
If both FACs fail or if airspeed more than 380 knots.
And may return to the lowspeed configuration when the slats are extended

Questions.QuestionString: If ELAC 1 and 2 have failed: (Level 2)
Answers: Pitch control is provided by the FAC's
Pitch control is controlled by SEC 2 or SEC 1
Pitch control is controlled by the FCDC's

Questions.QuestionString: Rudder Travel Limit function is performed by: (Level 1)
FAC 1 controls and monitors one yaw damper, one electrical rudder trim motor and: (Level 3)
Answers: One electrical motor for the rudder travel limitation unit
One servo actuator on each elevator

Questions.QuestionString: Flaps(Slats) will be locked in case of: (Level 2)
Answers: Assymetry or runaway or overspeed or uncommanded movement detected.
Assymetry or runaway or overload or uncommanded movement detected.
Assymetry or runaway or overrange or uncommanded movement detected.

Questions.QuestionString: In case of failure of both servo controls of the same aileron, the other aileron is: (Level 1)
High lift function of A321 A/C is achieved by: (Level 1)
Answers: 4 Slats and 2 Flaps on each wing.
5 Slats and 2 Flaps on each wing.
6 Slats and 2 Flaps on each wing.

Questions.QuestionString: What happens if an electric trim motor of THS actuator fails (Level 1)
Answers: THS electric trim is fully available

Questions.QuestionString: Where are the Wing Tib Brakes of Slat located? (Level 1)
Answers: At the wing tip, outboard of the APPU
Between track 11 and 12, in each wing.
Between track 7 and 8, in each wing.

Questions.QuestionString: Which spoilers are used as speed brake function (Level 1)
The aileron droop function means: (Level 3)
Answers: The ailerons are deflected downwards when the flaps are extended.
he ailerons are deflected downwards when the flaps are retracted.
he ailerons are deflected upwards when the flaps are extended.

Questions.QuestionString: A computer arrangement permanently controls and monitors the flight control surfaces, it also records and stores faults. This arrangement includes: (Level 3)
What is the correct? (Level 3)
Answers: There are two FACs (FAC 1 and FAC 2) are installed on the A/C. An inoperative FAC 1 is a NO GO item. FAC 2 may be inoperative and deactivated provided all MMEL restrictions are applied.
There are two FACs (FAC 1 and FAC 2) are installed on the A/C. An inoperative FAC 2 is a NO GO item. FAC 1 may be inoperative and deactivated provided all MMEL restrictions are applied.
There are two FACs (FAC 1 and FAC 2) are installed on the A/C. Both FACs may be inoperative and deactivated provided all MMEL restrictions are applied.

Questions.QuestionString: To Extend/ Retract Spoiler actuator manually: (Level 2)
Answers: You can not do without hydraulic power.
You can do without specific tool.
You can do with specific unlocking tool.

Questions.QuestionString: Each elevator is powered by two actuators, which are controlled by ELAC1 and ELAC2. What is the correct? (Level 3)
Answers: ELAC 1 controls the green and yellow actuators and ELAC 2 controls the blue actuators.
ELAC 2 controls the green and yellow actuators and ELAC 1 controls the blue actuators.
ELAC 2 controls the green and blue actuators and ELAC 1 controls the yellow and blue actuators.

Questions.QuestionString: The THS ball hydraulic motors are control by? (Level 2)
Answers: One of the three electric motors.
One of the three electric motors or Trim wheels.
One of the three electric motors or Pedals.

Questions.QuestionString: If the normal law of both ELACs fails, the alternate law takes over. (Level 2)
In case of failure of ELAC1 servo control on L/H aileron, (Level 3)
In case of failure of a spoiler servo control: (Level 2)
Answers: The opposite spoiler surface is retracted.
All spoilerssurfacesin the same wing are retracted.

Questions.QuestionString: What is the maximum deflection of A321 Rudder? (Level 2)
Which Compter send rudder trim command to FAC? (Level 2)
Answers: ELACs in manual flight, FMGCs in auto flight.
ELACs in auto flight, FMGCs in manual flight.

Questions.QuestionString: If the Angle-Of-Attack (AOA) protection is activated with speed brakes extended, (Level 3)
Answers: The speed brakes are still extended.

Questions.QuestionString: When Flaps are in fully extended postion, spoilers are: (Level 1)
How many solenoid valves in each slat pcu block valve? (Level 1)
Where is the Command Sensor Unit of Slats/ Flaps systems located? (Level 1)
SFCCs get the actual position of Slats/ Flaps through signal of position sensors. What are the sensors? (Level 3)
As the flap extends to the requested position, (Level 2)
The flap disconnect sensors, which are proximity sensors, detect any flap disconnection. It sends the signal to: (Level 3)
If one hydraulic system fails: (Level 3)
Answers: Only the roll and pitch axes are available
All the three axes are available with some roll spoiler retraction
Manual pitch trim and rudder are available

Questions.QuestionString: When both side sticks are moved in the same or opposition direction: (Level 3)
Answers: The surface movement is proportional to the algebraic sum of the deflection of both side sticks
The surface movement is proportional to the last stick deflection
The surface movement follows the captain's side stick deflection

Questions.QuestionString: In normal conditions, what are the active protections in flare mode? (Level 2)
Answers: Bank angle and high speed protections.

Questions.QuestionString: With one flap PCU motor inoperative, the flap system: (Level 2)
Answers: Is locked by the pressure off brakes on both wings.

Questions.QuestionString: Wing Tip Brakes are actived in flight: (Level 2)
Answers: They can be reset as soon as all fault of Slats/ Flaps systems gone.
They can be reset on ground when A/C has electrical power.
They can be reset on ground when A/C has hydraulic power (electrical pumps operate).

Questions.QuestionString: If one control valve or its driving mechanism of THS actuator is jammed, what will happen? (Level 3)
Answers: One hydraulic motor will be cut and THS will stop.
Both hydraulic motors will be cut.
One hydraulic motor will be cut andTHS will operate at half speed

Questions.QuestionString: When the elevator servo control is in the active mode. What is the correct? (Level 3)
Answers: One solenoid valve is de-energized and the other is energized.

Questions.QuestionString: With complete EFCS (ELECTRIC FLIGHT CONTROL SYSTEM) failure the rudder and THS are: (Level 3)
What effect on the slat and flap system will failure of SFCC 2 cause? (Level 3)
Answers: Flap system operates at half speed.
Slat and flap systems operate at half speed.
Slat and flap systems are locked.

Questions.QuestionString: What signals cause the rudder pedal movement? (Level 3)
